Question: Consider a 2D shape that looks like the letter 'F'.

If this shape is rotated 90 degrees clockwise, then 180 degrees counterclockwise, what would it look like compared to its original position? Use the following orientation for the original 'F': the vertical line is on the left, with two horizontal lines extending to the right - one at the top and one in the middle.

Solution:

Now, the next rotation is 180 degrees counterclockwise.
I need to apply this rotation to the already rotated 'F' shape.
Rotating 180 degrees counterclockwise is the same as rotating 180 degrees clockwise because it's a full half-circle.

Rotating this 180 degrees counterclockwise will flip it so that the horizontal line is now at the top, and the vertical lines are on the left side.

So, any point that was on the right side will now be on the left side, and vice versa.
Also, the orientation of the lines will invert.
So, after the first rotation, the horizontal line was at the bottom, and the two vertical lines were on the right.
After rotating 180 degrees counterclockwise, the horizontal line will move to the top, and the vertical lines will move to the left.
The direction of the vertical lines will also change: if they were pointing upwards before, they will now point downwards.
